items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.70mAOD at 17:45 on 24/02/2023 and 4.73mAOD at 05:30 on 25/02/2023.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 38 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the nextÂ five days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 25/02/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: Water levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: Tide water levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. However, there is potential for flood risk from high tides during the evening of Friday 24th February, and we will keep you informed of any changes. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed.  Spring high tide levels are now forecast to have fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary

items.description: Tidal flooding near the South Humber Bank from Barton Upon Humber to Humberston

floodArea.county: Lincolnshire, North East Lincolnshire, North Lincolnshire

items.message: Stormy conditions have now past, and the risk of tidal flooding along the South Humber Bank has now reduced and has fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: Tidal flooding near the South Humber Bank from Whitton to South Ferriby
items.message: Stormy conditions have now past, and the risk of flooding from the Humber Estuary has now reduced and has fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
